title: Australia loses 124,000 millionaires due to dollar, property prices
text:
"The report reveals the large proportion of wealth tied up in housing, emphasising the importance of real estate conditions to confidence and economic activity," Credit Suisse Australia chief investment officer Andrew McAuley said.

Non-financial assets, including real estate, accounted for 58 per cent of gross assets of total household wealth in Australia, compared to just 35 per cent in the US, 39 per cent in Japan and 45 per cent in Switzerland.

"The high level of real assets reflects a large endowment of land and natural resources relative to the population, but also high property prices in the largest cities," the report says.

Mr McAuley told The Australian Financial Review that the nation's fading fortunes on the global ranking was evidence of over-exposure of Australians to a single asset class.

"Between 2018 and 2019 the house price decline of 6 per cent in Australia is the only recorded instance of a drop of more than 2 per cent among all the nations forming part of the report," he said. "It is essential for investors to have a multi-asset class portfolio, mixing foreign assets and AUD assets."

He said exposure to emerging markets, particularly China and India, which saw total household wealth growth rates of 3.1 per cent and 5.2 per cent respectively, was especially critical.

Wealthy resilience

Advertisement

Despite the 6 per cent decline in average wealth, and diminished position on the global rankings, Australia's wealth outlook remains resilient, the report says.

The proportion of Australians with wealth above $US100,000 was found to be 66 per cent. The report's authors – Professor Anthony Shorrocks of the University of Manchester, Professor Jim Davies of the University of Western Ontario and Rodrigo Lluberas, an analyst at the Uruguay Central Bank – said this figure was "one of the highest in any country and about six times the world average".

A total of 1.3 million Australians sit within the top 1 per cent of global wealth holders, with Australia accounting for 2.6 per cent of this ultra high net worth demographic. This was despite contributing just 0.4 per cent to the world's total adult population.

Australia currently has 1.18 million USD millionaires, up from just 108,000 in 2000, the report says.

"While the economic environment since the 2018 report has become more challenging in Australia, with sub-trend GDP growth and a weaker property market, the growth seen across investment markets has ensured Australia retained its consistently strong position as one of the wealthiest countries globally," Credit Suisse Australia head of private banking Michael Marr said.

All things being equal

Australia's relatively high representation in the ultra-high net worth demographic has not come at the expense of inequality, the report found.

The country has a Gini coefficient – the statistical measure of wealth inequality – of 66 per cent, well below that of Canada (72.8 per cent), the United Kingdom (74.6 per cent), Germany (81.6 per cent), India (83.2 per cent) and the United States (85.2 per cent). Just 7 per cent of Australians have a net worth of below $US10,000.

"Australia remains one of the countries with one of the most even distributions of income across its population out of all the countries in the report," Mr Marr said.
description: Average wealth per adult in Australia has fallen from $US411,060 to $US386,060 in the past 12 months, according to Credit Suisse.
